metadata.title: Interstitial Cystitis (Painful Bladder Syndrome)  Occupational Therapy
synonyms: painful bladder syndrome (interstitial cystitis)  occupational therapy
tic douloureux of bladder: occupational therapy
occupational therapy: interstitial cystitis (painful bladder syndrome)
anatomical location body part affected: Urinary and renal system(s); includes the upper urinary tract, kidneys, ureters, lower urinary tract, urinary bladder (including detrusor muscle), urethra, urinary meatus, internal and external urinary sphincters, and pelvic floor muscles
description: Interstitial cystitis (IC) is a clinical syndrome characterized by suprapubic pain that appears related to bladder filling and is accompanied by additional symptoms such as increased daytime and nighttime frequency of urination in the absence of known infection or other pathology.(1) IC can vary in its presentation from mild to severe;(2) onset is gradual and worsens over the course of 5 to 15 years(1)

ICD-10 codes.N30.10: interstitial cystitis (chronic) without hematuria (ICD codes are provided for the reader’s reference, not for billing purposes)

reimbursement: Reimbursement for therapy will depend on insurance contract coverage; no specific special agencies are applicable for this condition
presentation signs and symptoms: The symptoms of IC vary from patient to patient but can include
suprapubic pain(1,3) –Worse with bladder filling and urination; relieved upon bladder emptying(1,3)
urinary urgency and frequency (more than 8 times during the day; more than twice at night)(1,3)
pelvic floor muscle spasms(4) –Many individuals with IC have high-tone  pelvic floor dysfunction(5)
submucosal petechiae (red, purple, or brown pinpoint spots that appear due to bleeding under the skin) or ulcers seen on cystoscopicexamination(3)
tenderness of –lower abdomen(1) –prostate to digital rectal examination (in men)(1)  –levatorani (in women)(1) –anterior vaginal wall/bladder neck (in women)(1) –pelvic floor muscles(5)

urinary incontinence in individuals with severe IC due to poor bladder wall compliance and small true bladder capacity(2) –For additional information on assessment and treatment of individuals who are incontinent of urine, see  Clinical Review… Incontinence, Urinary (Occupational Therapy)  ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T709021 Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: Be aware of patient pain throughout the evaluation, especially during any palpation; discontinue anything that causes or exacerbates pain immediately
The clinician should have special training to do internal exams and should obtain consent prior to the start of examination

causes: the cause of ic is unknown: Possible causes include–congenital or acquired defect in the bladder epithelium (glycosaminoglycans layer)–urothelium permeability–mast cell histamine release–neural upregulation–genetics–infection
pathogenesis: ic is marked by noninfect: Many, but not all, individuals with IC will have Hunner’s ulcers (areas of inflammation on the bladder wall) andglomerulations (submucosal bladder hemorrhages)(1,6)

Abnormalities may be present in various levels of bladder tissue including(34)–reduced urothelial layer–impaired storage capacity–atypical smooth muscle cell pattern–high microvascular density–high density of mast cells and nerve fibers
risk factors: Race (95% of patients with IC are White women)(1,2)
Age (most prevalent in 4thand 5th decades of life)(1)
History of urinary tract infections (UTIs) is a possible risk factor(33)
A history of dysmenorrhea has been associated with IC(28)

overall contraindications precautions: See specific  Contraindications/precautions to examination   and  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/

contraindications precautions to examina: Be aware of patient pain throughout the evaluation, especially during any palpation; discontinue anything that causes or exacerbates pain immediately
The clinician should have special training to do internal exams and should obtain consent prior to the start of examination

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Mechanism of injury or etiology of illness -When was IC first diagnosed in the patient? -IC is a diagnosis of exclusion when nothing else can be found to explain a patient’s symptoms; there is no definitive diagnostic test(1,3) -Review the patient’s medication history and physical examination as well as laboratory tests (described below) -As part of the patient’s medical evaluation, the patient may have been asked to complete a bladder diary(1)  -Information that may be tracked in a bladder diary -Time(s) of day the patient uses the toilet -Amount of urine voided in the toilet -Amount of urine (if any) leaked throughout the day -Patient’s activity at the time of leakage -Whether the patient felt an urge prior to or during leakage -Fluid intake throughout the day -Use of absorbent pads and or diapers throughout the day -Frequency and consistency of bowel movements -This information may be helpful during an occupational therapy evaluation and when determining an appropriate treatment plan; request that the patient bring any diary/log with them to the evaluation for review -The diary of a patient with IC will likely show a pattern of low volume (< 100 mL) and high-frequency  voiding(1) -Inquire about association with menses if the patient is female and premenopausal or perimenopausal

course of treatment.medical management: Document any current and/or prior medical and/or surgical intervention for IC  there is no consensus on optimal management Management should begin with more conservative treatment options (e.g., patient education, stress and pain management, pelvic floor muscle massage and/or myofascial release, and bladder retraining). Other options include oral medication and intravesicaltherapies,cystoscopic interventions, and surgery (e.g., neuromodulation)(31,32) Surgery is used only for patients with extreme pain from IC who do not find relief from any other medical intervention(1) Implantable sacral neuromodulation (e.g., InterStim) is the most common surgical intervention for IC; surgery involves placing a pacemaker for the bladder that reestablishes appropriate neuromodulation of the bladder(1,6) In a randomized crossover trial conducted in the United States of sacral versus pudendal nerve stimulation for IC, researchers found that patients had better pain relief with pudendal nerve stimulation(7) Laser ablation, fulguration, or resection might be used to remove Hunner’sulcers(1) Intravesical botulinum toxin A injections Based on a 2020 Cochrane systematic review, botulinum toxin A may improve the rate of cure or improvement, but may not reduce pain in adults with IC(35)
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications the physician has prescribed. Are they being taken? Are they effective? A course of antibiotics is often attempted as initial pharmacotherapy(1) Analgesia (e.g., acetaminophen or ibuprofen) may be recommended for symptomatic relief from IC(37) NSAIDs have been reported to increase IC symptoms in up to 10% of patients(36) Pentosanpolysulfate sodium is the only drug approved by the U.S. FDA to treat IC(1,31) Typically takes 3 to 6 months before maximum benefit from drug treatment is achieved(1) Medication should be stopped if symptoms don’t improve after 6 months. Long-term  use (> 3 years) can have detrimental vision side effects(31) Tricyclic antidepressants (e.g., amitriptyline)(1) Antihistamines (e.g., hydroxyzine,cimetidine)(1) Patients taking hydroxyzine have demonstrated up to 90% reduction in IC symptoms and patients taking cimetidine up to 57% reduction in IC symptoms(31) Neuroleptics (e.g., gabapentin, topiramate)(1) Antimuscarinics(1) Oral prednisone is prescribed for patients with Hunner’sulcers(1) Intravesical therapy (medication placed directly into the bladder via catheter) is sometimes used as long-term  therapy if oral medications are not effective, for acute flareups,  or before oral medications reach their maximum benefit(1,3)  Dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) is the only FDA-approved  intravesical treatment for IC; however, other medications are sometimes used (such as heparin)(1,3) Authors of a meta-analysis  that included 3 studies with data from 213 patients total reported that intravesical 2% chondroitin sulphate was an effective therapy for some patients with IC(23) DMSO is associated with side effects such as a garlic-like  odor or taste on the breath or skin that lasts up to 72 hours after a treatment(1) Sildenafil (Viagra, Revatio), a vasodilator, provides relief from urinary urgency and pain(27) Based on a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled  trial in China that included 48 women with IC Authors of a review (81 RCTs and 4674 patients) examined different treatment options for IC. Of 65 differentantidepressants, pentosan polysulfate, and neuromuscular blockade(38) Because the evidence was rated of very low quality, not many conclusions were drawn. They did find that treatment with antidepressants and pentosan polysulfatemay be more likely to improve or cure symptoms in patients with IC than neuromuscular blockade
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed:  Usual tests for this condition are the following:
Performed to look for evidence of hematuria (blood in the urine), pyuria (pus in the urine), glycosuria (glucose in the urine), or proteinuria (excessive protein in the urine)(1,8)
Urine specimen may also be sent for further cytologic examination when hematuria or irritative voiding symptoms are present(8)
Urine is cultured for presence of bacteria/infection; forIC to be diagnosed, the culture must be negative for bacteria/ infection(1,3,8)
May include abdominal and/or pelvic ultrasound and/or CT to rule out other pathologies(1)
Anesthetic bladder challenge: an anesthetic cocktail is administered into the bladder to test if symptoms disappear(1)

In individuals with IC, cystoscopy and hydrodistension (bladder is distended with fluid) under general anesthesia often show terminal hematuria (blood at the end of the urine stream), glomerulations, Hunner’s ulcers, and small bladder capacity of less than 200–350  mL(1,3,6)
Bladder biopsy and urodynamics are not typically recommended as part of a medical workup for IC(9)
Authors of a study conducted in Taiwan with 214 participants found that urodynamic studies might be helpful for diagnosis and prognostication for IC; however, additional research is necessary(25)
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether they help(1) Patients sometimes self-medicate  with urinary chelating agents such as Polycitra-K  crystals or Urocit-K,  Prelief (an OTC food additive), or herbal remedies such as aloe vera or CystaQ; however, there is no evidence to establish that these are effective treatments for IC(1) Authors of a case study reported on a 17-year-old  female patient with a 2-year  history of IC.The patient was treated with a combination of pentosan polysulfateand complementary and alternative medicine (CAM) treatment, consisting of biotherapeutic drainage, homeopathic medications, and journaling. Within 6 months of starting this treatment protocol, the patient’s symptoms resolved and had not returned as of a 2year  follow-up(22) Authors of a study conducted in the United States surveyed 53 women with IC to determine the extent to which they included CAM in their treatment regimens.(26) Of the women surveyed, 51% reported using some type of CAM in addition to conventional medical management. Diet modification was the most frequently reported type of CAM; others included supplements, herbs, and acupuncture(26)
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Determine what, if any, factors appear to worsen or alleviate pain or other symptoms  -Suprapubic pain associated with IC is typically worsened by filling of the bladder and alleviated with emptying of the bladder(1) -Exercise(1) -Emotional and physical stress(1,4) -Sexual activity(1) -Ejaculation(1) -Foods high in potassium and acid (including beer, spices, bananas, tomatoes, chocolate, strawberries, artificial sweeteners, oranges, cranberries, and caffeine)(1,2) -Menstruation(1) -Prolonged sitting(1) -Activation of allergies(1)
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms. Common symptoms include -suprapubic pain(1) -The pain in IC can range from dull and achy to sharp and stabbing(6) -urinary urgency and frequency(1) -dyspareunia(1) -dysphoric mood(1) -lower abdomen(1) -prostate to digital rectal examination (in men)(1) -levator ani (in women)(1) -anterior vaginal wall/bladder neck (in women)(1) -pelvic floor muscles(5)
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much) -Pain associated with IC is suprapubic(1) -The intensity of symptoms tends to wax and wane in individuals with IC(1)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (A.M., mid-day,  P.M., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of wakings/night -IC can result in sleep disturbance(2) -Does the patient wake up frequently at night to urinate or due to pain in the bladder?
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to a physician (e.g., migraines, gastrointestinal problems, dizziness, sexual dysfunction, bowel/bladder incontinence)
history of present illness.respiratory status: Note the patient’s respiratory rate -Does the patient require supplemental oxygen? Nasal cannula? -Does the patient have a tracheostomy tube? -Does the patient require ventilator support? Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe _______________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Previous history of same/similar diagnosis Previous history of urinary incontinence, childhood bedwetting, and/or bowel dysfunction or incontinence?  History of sexually transmitted infection (STI)? History of UTIs? Previous surgical history Is there a history of pelvic, urological, gynecological, or penile surgery?
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask the patient about other problems, including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, complications of pregnancy, psychiatric disorders, and orthopedic disorders Diagnosis of IC is often associated with other diagnoses such as irritable bowel syndrome, migraine, endometriosis, skin sensitivities, multiple drug allergies, other allergies, vulvodynia, fibromyalgia, chronic fatigue syndrome, systematic lupus erythematosus (SLE), and depression/mood disorders(1,2) Authors of a study conducted in the United States with 276 women with IC found that the presence of fibromyalgia, chronic fatigue syndrome, or irritable bowel syndrome has a significant negative association with healthrelated QOL(24)
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask the patient about other symptoms he or she may be experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Vocation/avocation and associated repetitive behaviors, if any -Does the patient’s IC disrupt their ability to perform their job? -Many patients with IC find it difficult to maintain full-time  employment(6) -Does the patient’s IC prevent them from participating in activities or leaving the house? -Once rapport with the patient is established, inquire about the effect of IC on sexual intercourse. Is the patient sexually active? Does the patient experience exacerbation of symptoms during sexual intercourse? Is the patient avoiding intercourse due to pain or symptoms?
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Functional limitations/assistance with ADLs/adaptive equipment -Does the patient require hearing aids? Are the hearing aids in good working order? -To maximize benefits of therapy, the occupational therapist (OT) should ensure that older adult patients with hearing loss have their hearing aids in good working order -Does the patient wear glasses? -Does the patient require an ambulatory device? -Does the patient use a wheelchair? -Any assistive devices needed to complete ADLs?
social and occupational history.living environment: Stairs, number floors in home, with whom patient lives, caregivers, etc. Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary? -Is there easy access to the toilet in the home and at work? Does the patient have to climb stairs to access the toilet?

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Assess the patient’s need for and/or use of assistive and adaptive devices. Is the equipment in good working order? –Toileting equipment -Grab bars next to the toilet? -Bedside commode? -A urinal at bedside? -Raised toilet seat? -Elevated footrest at the toilet?  –Other equipment -Does the patient require a cane, walker, wheelchair, crutches, orthotics or braces, special shoes, or other equipment for mobility? -If so, assess the patient’s ability to correctly use these devices to get himself or herself to the toilet
relevant tests and measures.balance: Evaluate static and dynamic balance reactions in sitting and standing –Tinetti Balance Scale may be used(11)Bed mobility and transfers should be assessed to determine the amount of assistance needed for the patient to perform each activity –Test static and dynamic activities(12) -Timed Up and Go (TUG) test(13) – a measurement of mobility -Includes tasks such as standing from a seating position, walking, turning, stopping, and sitting down, all of which are important for independent mobility –ROM and grip strength(12) -Does the patient have sufficient ROM and flexibility to complete toileting independently? -Is grip strength sufficient for toileting? –Functional Independence Measure (FIM) – an 18-item,  7-level ordinal scale(14)
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Observe the patient’s gait and ability to climb stairs (assisted or unassisted) –If the patient presents with impaired gait, referral to physical therapy may be appropriate
observation inspection palpation includi: Patients with severe IC who have urinary incontinence are at risk for skin breakdown, dermatitis, pressure ulcers, rashes, and secondary yeast infections due to leakage of urine(15,16) •Perception (e.g., visual field, spatial relations): Note the patient’s vision and hearing skills
If during the exam it appears that the patient has altered perception, refer to audiology, ophthalmology, or neurology for further testing •Self-care/activities  of daily living  (objective testing)
FIM and the Barthel Index of Activities of Daily Living are appropriate standardized measures for ADLs(14,17,18)

Assess safety and ability to perform ADLs: brushing teeth, combing hair, dressing upper and lower extremities, managing clothing, using the toilet, applying makeup or shaving the face, bathing, eating

Perform an in-depth  assessment of toileting for patients with IC -How much and what type of assistance is needed when using the toilet? -If the patient does require caregiver assistance, do they have this help readily available in their living environment? -Does the patient require assistance wiping or otherwise cleaning while using the toilet? -Is the patient able to wipe adequately with the correct technique? -Do they require an assistive device for adequate wiping? •Sensation

Briefly assess patient’s sensation, including touch sensation as well as spatial awareness and olfactory sensation(12) -Touch sensation and olfaction are important for patients with IC who have urinary incontinence as these senses help them realize if they have been incontinent of urine(12)
Tests for touch sensation include normal touch, light touch, pinprick, position sensation, vibration, and temperature
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests specific to diagnosis –Validated questionnaires(1,9) -Pelvic Pain and Urgency/Frequency (PUF) scale(1,2,4) -O’Leary-Sant  symptom and problem index(1) -Wisconsin Interstitial Cystitis Scale(1,9) -Interstitial Cystitis Problem Index (ICPI)(9) -Interstitial Cystitis Symptom Index (ICSI)(9) –Fluid intake(29) -Ask the patient/caregiver to describe the typical amount and type of fluids that the patient drinks each day  -Does the patient frequently consume beverages such as soda, coffee, or tea that contain caffeine? -Caffeine is a bladder irritant and may exacerbate urinary urgency and frequency -Carbonated beverages should also be avoided for all types of incontinence
relevant tests and measures.arousal attention cognition: A brief cognitive assessment such as the Mini-Mental  State Examination (MMSE)(10) is appropriate for patients with IC –If the patient appears to have significant cognitive deficits, refer to a neurologist, neuropsychologist, and/or speech-language  pathologist (SLP) for further workup

contraindications precautions: Over the trunk or heart region in patients with demand-type pacemakers and implantable cardioverter defibrillators (ICDs)
Over the pelvic, abdominal, lumbar, or hip region of a pregnant woman
Over the phrenic nerve, eyes, or gonads
Over areas of known peripheral vascular disease
With patients with compromised mental ability
With cardiac dysfunction (uncontrolled hypertension or hypotension, irregular heartbeat)
With electrodes -Over compromised skin, unless treating wound specifically -Over tissues that are vulnerable to hemorrhage -Cervical region in patients with history of stroke or seizures
Do not use within 5 yards of diathermy units or other source of electromagnetic radiation
other: Only those contraindications/precautions applicable to this diagnosis are mentioned below, including with regard to modalities. Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgment

Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician. The summary below is meant to serve as a guide, not to replace orders from a physician or a clinic’s specific protocols
Manual therapy precautions/contraindications (may vary according to technique)

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Patients with IC may benefit from occupational therapy intervention for pain and symptom management. IC can disrupt normal life and decrease QOLfor patients(39)
assessment plan of care.rule out: The patient’s medical team will rule out and treat other possible causes of painful bladder prior to diagnosing IC, including: benign prostatic hyperplasia(1) bladder neoplasm(2) bladder stone(2) chemical cystitis (cyclophosphamide)(3) chronic nonbacterial prostatitis(1) chronic pelvic pain(1) endometriosis(1) frequent vaginitis(1) genital herpes(3) neurologic bladder disease(2) overactive bladder(1) pelvic adhesions(1)  radiation cystitis(3) recurrent UTI(1) uninhibited bladder(2) urethral diverticulum(3) urethral pain syndrome(1) vaginitis(3) vulvar vestibulitis(1) vulvodynia(1)
prognosis: Up to 50% of patients will experience spontaneous remission of symptoms without treatment(3)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Referrals to the following disciplines may be appropriate for patients with IC Referral to a urologist if patient presents with urinary incontinence and is not responding to medical and behavioral interventions(19) Referral to physical therapy if the patient has difficulty with gait, ambulation, transfers, or weight-bearing  or if incontinence is caused or exacerbated by restricted mobility. Referral to a physical therapist (PT) specializing in treatment of IC may be beneficial for pelvic floor myofascial dysfunction Referral to speech therapy if the patient presents with speech, language, cognitive, or swallowing problems Referral to audiology if the patient appears to have hearing loss Referral to psychology if patient appears depressed, anxious, or otherwise emotionally compromised as a result of incontinence(6) Referral to a physician if patient presents with recurrent UTIs; refer to a physician if the patient appears to have skin breakdown or irritation due to wet undergarments and/or clothes(15) Pain specialist Psychologist for possible stress management, relaxation exercises
treatment summary: Patient education –Education on normal bladder function, chronic nature of IC, lack of cure, disease management, and treatment strategies(33,37)

Stress and pain management –Sitz baths, ice, and heating pads(1) –TENS(6) –Stress management techniques may include breathing techniques, meditation, exercise, or any other activity that helps the patient manage stress-induced  symptom exacerbations(31) –Counseling and psychological support may improve patients’ symptoms by about 45-50%(32)

Pelvic floor muscle massage and/or myofascial release –Patients with trigger point tenderness, hypertonicity, and/or spasm in the pelvic floor may benefit from myofascial release or intravaginal massage(31,32) -This can lead to symptomatic improvement in about 50–60%  of patients(32) –Authors of a multicenter randomized clinical trial of myofascial physical therapy for women with IC conducted at centers across the United States found that a significantly higher proportion of women with IC in the trial responded to treatment with myofascial physical therapy than to global therapeutic massage(20) -PTs trained and certified in myofascial physical therapy performed the interventions -Eighty-one  participants were randomized into either a myofascial physical therapy treatment group or a global massage group; 78 participants completed the study -Subjects received up to ten 60-minute  treatment sessions over a 12-week  period and were not aware if they were receiving a global massage program or the experimental myofascial physical therapy treatment  -At follow-up,  59% of the participants in the myofascial physical therapy treatment group reported moderate to marked improvement of symptoms and only 26% of individuals in the control/global massage group reported moderate to marked improvement of symptoms

Bladder retraining(1) –Bladder retraining can help to reduce symptoms of urgency, reduce urinary frequency, and increase the volume of urine the bladder can hold in patients with IC(31) -Patient starts by voiding on a schedule based on the interval recorded in a urinary diary(19) -Each week, the patient is trained to increase the interval by 30 minutes, trying to utilize relaxation strategies to postpone the need to void(19,29) -The goal is usually 3–4 hours between voids(29) -Patients with cognitive impairments may be able to use this method given assistance from a caregiver or family member(19) -When an urge is felt the patient should use pelvic floor muscle exercises to help lessen the urge(31) -The patient is instructed to contract the muscle they use to stop the flow of urine or hold in flatulence(19,21) -For urge incontinence, pelvic floor muscles exercises are also used to delay voiding and reduce the urinary urgency(29) -When the urge to urinate comes on, patients are trained to consciously focus on delaying the urge and waiting for it to pass before they void the bladder -Patients are encouraged to resist voiding the bladder during a strong urge, as voiding while the bladder is irritated can exacerbate urinary incontinence -Patients are taught to stop all activity, stand still, and breathe normally while contracting the pelvic floor muscles rapidly 5–6 times until the urge diminishes -Some patients find that distraction, such as counting backwards from 100 or humming a song, helps to reduce the urge to urinate

According to the American Urological Association, patients with IC should avoid pelvic floor strengthening exercises such as Kegel exercises(33) . Problem Goal Intervention Expected Progression Home Program Suprapubic pain Reduce or eliminate suprapubic pain associated with ICTherapeutic modalities _ Sitz baths, ice, and heating pads(1) _ _ Pelvic floor muscle massage and/or myofascial release _ _ Bladder retraining _ See Treatment summary , aboveMassage and myofascial trigger points to be progressed according to individual patient’s tolerance and specific amount of muscle tenderness/ hypertonicity _ Gradually progress time between voidsInvolve partners in treatment discussions .

maintenance or prevention: Patients with IC should avoid activities and/or foods that are associated with flare-ups  if possible(1)
Patients with IC should not smoke cigarettes(1)
Early identification and treatment of IC generally results in better outcomes for the patient(1)
patient education: Patients should be educated on behavior modifications related to altering their diet, managing their fluid intake, and managing their stress
Information for patients including general education and support groups is available on the Interstitial Cystitis Association (ICA) website at https://www.ichelp.org/

Patient education materials are available at UrologyHealth.org, the official website of the American Urological Association Foundation. General information about IC is available at http://www.urologyhealth.org/urologic-conditions/interstitial-cystitis?article=67
